Katitu Momambo, 
 the clever litle girl 
 
 Traditional San story 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time there lived thre girls
 in a desert vilage in the Kalahari. Katitu
 
 Momambo was the youngest of the 
 thre. She was smal but clever and wise.
 
 
 The big girls went into the veld one day
 to gather fod and wod. Litle Katitu ran
 after them, but the sisters sent her back.
 
 “Go back Katitu! You are to smal to go
 with us! Stay at home!” they said.
 
 
 Katitu folowed them from a distance.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 When they noticed her, they were to far 
 
 away from home to send her back, so 
 she joined them. 
 
 
 While she was walking behind them, 
 Katitu cut herself some wod. She made 
 
 herself a bow and many arows. 
 
 The girls walked and walked and walked 
 
 until the sun droped into the Kalahari 
 horizon. They were lost. 
 
 
 They walked into a deserted vilage and 
 found a hut in which to spend the night. 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 An old woman was siting next to the
 
 hut. 
 
 Litle Katitu went and greted her.
 
 “Oh?” answered the old woman, “This is
 the vilage of the Big Snake! He stays in a
 big hole in the catle kral. When people
 
 come to milk the cows, he eats them! He
 wil go to your hut at night when you
 
 slep and kil you there!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Wise litle Katitu did not panic. She asked the old woman for a hard cow skin
 
 to cover the dor of their sleping hut. Then Katitu wanted to slep a litle,
 so that she could stay awake throughout the night. “When the wind begins
 to blow,” she said to her sisters, “you must wake me up.” 
 
 
 The wind came up, the sisters awoke Katitu and went to slep. Katitu fixed
 the hard cow skin against the dor of the hut and made a litle hole in the
 
 midle for her bow and arows. 
 
 
 Katitu heard the Big Snake aproach. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Hai, gom-gom, hai, gom-gom, where are
 
 they?” sang the Big Snake. 
 The litle clever girl answered him with a
 chant, “Here they are, here they are!”
 
 Then the Big Snake rushed against the
 hard skin at the dor of the hut. Litle
 Katitu shot an arow through the hole in
 
 the skin. 
 
 
 Yes, the litle girl kiled the Big Snake.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then Katitu woke up the older girls. 
 “Sister, sister, sister,” she whispered, “get 
 
 up, get up, get up!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 And when the girls woke up they saw a
 big snake lying there. 
 
 “Come, we have to take him back to his
 hole!” shouted Katitu. 
 They roled him up, roled him up, roled
 
 him up and they set him right back in his
 hole. 
 
 “Hury! We have to run!” And the girls ran
 and ran and ran. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next morning, the Big Snake’s wife told his children to go and lok for
 
 him. When his children found him lying dead in his hole, they screamed:
 “Father is dead! Quick, let us go after those girls!” 
 
 
 Al the snake’s children went after the girls. 
 
 Katitu told her sisters to turn into tres. When the snakes arived at the spot
 
 where they had sen the girls, only tres were standing there. The snakes
 were tired and lay under the tres to slep. When they were aslep, the girls
 
 turned back into human beings and ran on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The girls continued to run and were very
 tired and thirsty. Eventualy, they saw a
 
 waterhole! None of older sisters wanted
 to scop the water from the dep wel.
 They asked Katitu to climb in as she was
 
 the smalest. 
 
 “Wil you help me out of the wel if I climb
 
 into it?” asked Katitu. 
 “Yes,” they replied, “we wil help you.”
 
 Katitu went into the wel and scoped
 water for her sisters. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Each girl drank and then walked away. 
 They al left Katitu in the dep wel and 
 
 walked home. 
 
 Later that evening, the elephants came to 
 
 drink. One of them drank and left. 
 Another one drank and left. The last 
 elephant drank and swalowed Katitu 
 
 with the water! 
 
 
 A few drops of Katitu’s blod sprayed 
 onto the reds growing at the water hole. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 Meanwhile, Katitu’s sisters had arived home without any fod or wod.
 
 They were crying and told the family that Katitu was lost. Everyone started
 searching for her. 
 
 
 Katitu’s litle brother and his friend were searching to. They became very
 tired and rested next to a waterhole. They cut some reds to make 
 
 themselves flutes. When Katitu’s brother played on his flute, the flute sang
 by itself: 
 
 
 “Is this my brother who plays me, who plays me, 
 The other girls left me, left me and the elephant swalowed me, swalowed
 
 me!” 
 The boy rushed home and handed the red to his father, who played it. And
 again, the red sang: 
 
 “Is this my father who plays me, plays me? 
 The other girls left me, left me, and the elephant swalowed me, swalowed
 me!” 
 
 The father handed the red to Katitu’s mother, who played it. And again, the
 red sang: 
 
 “Is this my mother who plays me, plays me? 
 The other girls left me, left me, and the elephant swalowed me, swalowed
 1 
 me!”  
 
 
 
 
 
 Katitu’s father caled the young men of 
 
 the homestead and ordered them to find 
 the tracks of the elephants and find 
 
 Katitu. 
 
 The young men huried of. They met the 
 
 first group of elephants and asked them, 
 “Elephants, elephants, have you sen the 
 one who swalowed our girl?” 
 
 And the elephants sang: 
 “!a plaf! !a plaf! We trot lightly. We are so 
 
 light, we cary nothing!” 
 
 And they pased on. 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The young men met up with an old
 
 elephant in the bush and asked, “Old
 elephant, elephant, have you sen the
 one who swalowed our girl?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The old elephant sang: 
 “!a plaf! !a plaf! I trot lightly! I am so light, 
 
 I cary nothing!” 
 
 But now the young men heard a litle 
 
 voice in the bely of the elephant. 
 “Cut him open! Go on, cut him on his left 
 
 side, for I am siting on his left side!” said 
 the voice. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They held the old elephant down and cut open his bely. There was litle
 Katitu lying inside! The young men tok her out and caried her home. Katitu
 
 was welcomed as a hero by the vilagers. 
 
 And that is the tale of Katitu Mamombo. The wise litle girl who saved her
 
 sisters from the Big Snake, saved them from the snake’s children, and (with
 the help of her brother) saved herself from the bely of the elephant.
 
 
 Of course, her sisters were punished. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 Story notes 
 
 Ju|’hoan storyteler, Nxisae Magdaline Nxao, told a short version of this
 story in Dkar, Botswana, in 205 (Winberg 209). In 193, Sigrid Schmidt
 
 recorded another version from Paulina Oxoros in northern Namibia (Schmidt
 207: 59). This particular version was retold by Marlene Winberg in 2013 for
 the Cave to Cave European Union storyteling project in Spain, based on
 
 Nxao and Schmidt’s recording. The ‘clever litle girl’ belongs to a wel-known
 story type where a vulnerable young girl (or young boy), saves the lives of
 others, by engaging her wit and the power of words, rather than supernatural
 
 means to solve problems. 
 
 
 The ilustrations in this story are from story boards by Marlene Winberg,
 interpreted digitaly by Satsiri Winberg through manipulations of the
 Manyeka Art Colection of paintings made by San artists. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 16
